summary_points: Purpose: To alter the rates of the standard allowance, limited capability for work (LCW) element, and limited capability for work and work-related activity (LCWRA) element of Universal Credit, and the rates of income-related Employment and Support Allowance (ESA) for specific tax years.

Key Definitions: Key definitions include 'standard allowance' (s.1(6)(c)), 'LCWRA element' (s.3(2)(a)), 'pre-2026 claimant' (Sch.1, Reg.27A(1)), and 'severe conditions criteria claimant' (Sch.1, Reg.40A(2)).

Eligibility: Eligibility for the LCWRA element is differentiated for 'pre-2026 claimants', 'severe conditions criteria claimants', 'terminally ill' claimants, and 'any other claimant' (Sch.1, Reg.27(2)). 'Severe conditions criteria claimants' are those with lifelong, diagnosed conditions meeting Schedule 7 descriptors (Sch.1, Reg.40A(2)-(3)).

Obligations: The Secretary of State is obligated to ensure minimum amounts for the standard allowance (s.1(1)) and to increase protected LCWRA amounts or standard allowance (s.4(1)) and certain legacy ESA payments (s.5(3)) for tax years 2026-27 to 2029-30, based on CPI and uplift percentages.
Enforcement: The Act does not detail specific enforcement mechanisms for non-compliance, focusing instead on the Secretary of State's obligations to set and adjust benefit rates.

sections.definitions: Section 1(6)(a): "consumer prices index" means the all items consumer prices index published by the Statistics Board. Section 1(6)(b): a "relevant power" means the power in section 9(2) of the Welfare Reform Act 2012, or the power in section 150(2)(b) of the Social Security Administration Act 1992. Section 1(6)(c): "the standard allowance" means the allowance to be included in an award of universal credit under section 9(1) of the Welfare Reform Act 2012. Section 1(6)(d): the standard allowance "for" a tax year means the standard allowance applicable for any assessment period commencing on or after the first Monday of that tax year and before the first Monday of the following tax year, and for this purpose "assessment period" has the same meaning as in Part 1 of that Act. Section 1(7)(a): "tax year" means the 12 months beginning with 6 April in any year. Section 1(7)(b): "tax year 2025-26" means the tax year beginning on 6 April 2025 (and any corresponding expression in which two years are similarly mentioned is to be read in the same way). Section 3(2)(a): "the LCWRA element" has the meaning given by regulation 27 of the Universal Credit Regulations 2013. Section 3(2)(b): "the LCW element" has the meaning given by regulation 27 of the Universal Credit Regulations 2013 (so far as saved by paragraph 8 of Schedule 2 to the Employment and Support Allowance and Universal Credit (Miscellaneous Amendments and Transitional and Savings Provisions) Regulations 2017). Section 4(3)(a): "the protected LCWRA amount" means the amount of the LCWRA element that applies to a pre-2026 claimant, a severe conditions criteria claimant or a claimant who is terminally ill (within the meanings of the Universal Credit Regulations 2013). Section 4(3)(b): "the LCWRA element" has the meaning it has in section 3. Section 4(3)(c): "the standard allowance" means the allowance to be included in an award of universal credit under section 9(1) of the Welfare Reform Act 2012. Section 4(3)(d): reference to an amount or allowance "for" a tax year means the amount or allowance applicable for any assessment period commencing on or after the first Monday of that tax year and before the first Monday of the following tax year, and for this purpose "assessment period" has the same meaning as in Part 1 of that Act. Section 4(4)(a): the "relevant CPI percentage" for a tax year is the percentage by which the consumer prices index for the September before the start of the tax year is higher than it was for the September before that (or 0% if it is not higher). Section 4(4)(b): the "consumer prices index" means the all items consumer prices index published by the Statistics Board. Section 5(5)(a): an "amount of the ESA IR personal allowance" means an amount prescribed under section 4(2)(a) of the Welfare Reform Act 2007 that is not an amount of a premium specified in Part 3 of Schedule 4 to the Employment and Support Allowance Regulations 2008 or an amount in respect of housing costs. Section 5(5)(b): an "amount of an ESA IR disability premium" means an amount of the severe disability premium or enhanced disability premium specified in Part 3 of Schedule 4 to the Employment and Support Allowance Regulations 2008, so far as prescribed under section 4(2)(a) of the Welfare Reform Act 2007. Section 5(5)(c): "the ESA IR support component" means the amount specified in paragraph 13 of Part 4 of Schedule 4 to the Employment and Support Allowance Regulations 2008, so far as specified under section 4(6)(c) of the Welfare Reform Act 2007. Section 5(5)(d): "the ESA IR work-related activity component" means the amount specified in paragraph 12 of Part 4 of Schedule 4 to the Employment and Support Allowance Regulations 2008, so far as specified under section 4(6)(c) of the Welfare Reform Act 2007 for the purposes of cases falling within paragraphs 2 to 7 of Schedule 2 to the Employment and Support Allowance and Universal Credit (Miscellaneous Amendments and Transitional and Savings Provisions) Regulations 2017. Section 5(5)(e): a reference to an amount or component "for" a tax year means the amount applicable for any benefit week commencing on or after the first Monday of that tax year and before the first Monday of the following tax year, and for this purpose "benefit week" has the same meaning as in the Employment and Support Allowance Regulations 2008. Schedule 1, Regulation 2: "pre-2026 claimant" has the meaning in regulation 27A(1); "severe conditions criteria claimant" has the meaning in regulation 40A(2). Schedule 1, Regulation 27A(1): For the purposes of regulation 27, a claimant with limited capability for work and work-related activity is a "pre-2026 claimant" if the claimant was entitled at any time before 6 April 2026 to an award of universal credit that included the LCWRA element, and has been entitled to an award of universal credit that included the LCWRA element continuously from that time. Schedule 1, Regulation 40A(1): A claimant is a "severe conditions criteria claimant" if it has been determined that the claimant is a severe conditions criteria claimant on the basis of an assessment under this Part. Schedule 1, Regulation 40A(2): A claimant is a severe conditions criteria claimant on the basis of an assessment under this Part if the claimant has limited capability for work and work-related activity on the basis of an assessment under this Part (see regulation 40(2)), and at least one of the descriptors set out in Schedule 7 constantly applies to the claimant and will do so for the rest of the claimant’s life. Schedule 1, Regulation 40A(5): "NHS services" means health care services provided for the purposes of the health service continued under section 1(1) of the National Health Service Act 2006; section 1(1) of the National Health Service (Wales) Act 2006; section 1(1) of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978; or health and social care within the meaning of the Health and Social Care (Reform) Act (Northern Ireland) 2009 provided for the purposes of the system promoted under section 2(1) of that Act.
sections.responsibilities: Section 1(1): The Secretary of State is responsible for exercising a relevant power to secure that the amounts of the standard allowance for tax years 2026-27 to 2029-30 are at least the amounts calculated in accordance with subsection (2). Section 4(1): The Secretary of State is responsible for exercising the power in section 9(2) or 12(3) of the Welfare Reform Act 2012 to increase the protected LCWRA amount or any amount of the standard allowance for tax years 2026-27 to 2029-30, where necessary to achieve the result in subsection (2). Section 5(3): The Secretary of State is responsible for exercising the power in section 4(2)(a) or (6)(c) of the Welfare Reform Act 2007 to increase any amount of an ESA IR disability premium, the ESA IR support component, or any amount of the ESA IR personal allowance for tax years 2026-27 to 2029-30, where necessary to achieve the result in subsection (4). Schedule 2, Paragraph 1(1): The Department for Communities in Northern Ireland is responsible for exercising a relevant power to secure that the amounts of the standard allowance for tax years 2026-27 to 2029-30 are at least the amounts calculated in accordance with sub-paragraph (2).
sections.eligibility: Section 2(1): Differentiates LCWRA element amounts based on whether a claimant is a "pre-2026 claimant, a severe conditions criteria claimant or a claimant who is terminally ill" or "other than" these categories. Schedule 1, Regulation 27(2): An award to include LCWRA element is determined by reference to whether the claimant is (a) a pre-2026 claimant, (b) a severe conditions criteria claimant, (c) terminally ill, or (d) any other claimant. Schedule 1, Regulation 27A(1): A claimant is a "pre-2026 claimant" if they were entitled to an award of universal credit including the LCWRA element before 6 April 2026 and have been continuously entitled since. Schedule 1, Regulation 40A(1), (2), (3): A claimant is a "severe conditions criteria claimant" if determined so based on an assessment where they have limited capability for work and work-related activity and at least one Schedule 7 descriptor constantly applies for life, arising from a diagnosed specific bodily disease/disablement or mental illness/disablement. Schedule 1, Regulation 41(1), (2), (4), (5), (6): Specifies conditions under which assessments for limited capability for work or severe conditions criteria claimant status may or may not be carried out, including the requirement for "relevant evidence" for further assessments after a previous determination.
sections.payments: Section 1(1), (2), (4): Standard allowance for tax years 2026-27 to 2029-30 must be at least amounts calculated by taking the previous year's amount, increasing by the relevant CPI percentage, and then by the relevant uplift percentage (2.3% for 2026-27, 3.1% for 2027-28, 4.0% for 2028-29, 4.8% for 2029-30). Section 1(5): Subsections (1) and (2)(c) of section 150 of the Social Security Administration Act 1992 (annual up-rating of benefits) do not apply to any amount of the standard allowance for tax years ending with 5 April 2026, 2027, 2028, and 2029. Section 2(1): Inserts "claimant with limited capability for work and work-related activity, other than a pre-2026 claimant, a severe conditions criteria claimant or a claimant who is terminally ill" with an amount of "£217.26" into regulation 36 of the Universal Credit Regulations 2013. Section 3(1): Subsections (1) and (2) of section 150 of the Social Security Administration Act 1992 do not apply to the LCWRA element or the LCW element for tax years ending with 5 April 2026, 2027, 2028, and 2029. Section 4(2): For tax years 2026-27 to 2029-30, the sum of the protected LCWRA amount and an amount of the standard allowance must be at least the sum of those amounts for the previous tax year, increased by the relevant CPI percentage for the current tax year. Section 5(1): Section 1 applies to the amounts of the ESA IR personal allowance for tax years 2026-27 to 2029-30, with a modification to the relevant power. Section 5(2): Subsections (1) and (2) of section 150 of the Social Security Administration Act 1992 do not apply to any amount of an ESA IR disability premium, the ESA IR support component, or the ESA IR work-related activity component for tax years ending with 5 April 2026, 2027, 2028, and 2029. Section 5(4): For tax years 2026-27 to 2029-30, the sum of ESA IR disability premium, ESA IR support component, and ESA IR personal allowance must be at least the sum of those amounts for the previous tax year, increased by the relevant CPI percentage for the current tax year. Schedule 1, Regulation 27(4): Where the LCWRA element for each of two claimants is a different amount, the higher amount is to be included. Schedule 2, Paragraph 1(1), (2): For Northern Ireland, the standard allowance for tax years 2026-27 to 2029-30 must be at least amounts calculated by taking the previous year's amount and increasing by the relevant CPI percentage.

checks.evidence: Sections 1(6), 1(7), 3(2), 4(3), 4(4), 5(5) and Schedule 1, paragraphs 2, 4, and 6 explicitly define key terms such as 'consumer prices index', 'relevant power', 'standard allowance', 'tax year', 'LCWRA element', 'LCW element', 'protected LCWRA amount', 'relevant CPI percentage', 'ESA IR personal allowance', 'ESA IR disability premium', 'ESA IR support component', 'ESA IR work-related activity component', 'pre-2026 claimant', 'severe conditions criteria claimant', and 'NHS services'.

The Universal Credit Act 2025 primarily amends existing regulations (e.g., Universal Credit Regulations 2013, Welfare Reform Act 2012) regarding the amounts of universal credit elements and defines specific claimant categories for those elements (e.g., 'pre-2026 claimant' in Schedule 1, paragraph 4, and 'severe conditions criteria claimant' in Schedule 1, paragraph 6). It does not specify the general eligibility criteria for Universal Credit itself, but rather refers to other legislation where such criteria are established.

checks.rule: Act must specify responsibilities of the administering authority
checks.evidence: Sections 1(1), 4(1), 5(3) assign responsibilities to the 'Secretary of State'. Schedule 2, paragraph 1(1) assigns responsibilities to the 'Department for Communities in Northern Ireland'.

checks.rule: Act must include enforcement or penalties
checks.evidence: The Universal Credit Act 2025 does not contain any provisions for enforcement or penalties within the provided text.

checks.rule: Act must include payment calculation or entitlement structure
checks.evidence: Section 1(2) details the calculation for the standard allowance. Section 2(1) specifies a monetary amount for the LCWRA element. Section 4(2) outlines the calculation for the protected LCWRA amount.

checks.rule: Act must include record-keeping or reporting requirements
checks.evidence: The Universal Credit Act 2025, as provided, focuses on altering rates and definitions related to universal credit. It does not contain any explicit sections or provisions that mandate record-keeping or reporting requirements for any entity.
